values:
ok so i *might* have found the flash drive that had the long-lost wip stuff from the remix of of linen on it

and i *might* never know peace until that stupid bastard of a fic is no longer a rough draft

...i mean not many people know this but i actually died in 2004 and i am now a ghost that occasionally comes back to haunt the internet with my angstfic

sorry

(p.s. i just remade my tumblr so ballyharnon.tumblr.com really is me, if anyone cares)

(p.p.s. i don't think there's any point in keeping this friends-only anymore, i'll be gradually going back and unlocking the fic. lj fandom got p weird there for a while.)

I made myself a tumblr account today because migration. Now I just have to find and follow things and people and I can be a fandom lurker in the new world order. Follow me so I can find you? I'm sure I'll figure out how to follow people back soon, so. Also I joined Pottermore infinity years late to the party because omfg PoA, so I guess I'm RookDraconis28858. My wand is quite impressively small and I am, predictably, in Slytherin. EDIT 2/5/15: Turns out my original tumblr didn't last long but I just remade it, so, ya know, that really is me. If anyone cares.

I don't know when the word 'mashup' entered the human collective unconscious, but I think I like it. Someone needs to do a mashup of something with M*A*S*H*. Oh, oh, I know, a crossover with that movie about that old man who ties balloons to his house. (Was that funny? I can't decide.) Anyhow, though the word is relatively new, the concept has existed for ages, and one arena in which it seems always to work perfectly is in the combination and perversion of old fairy-tales. Fairy-tales, for those of you not familiar with the genre, are what white Europeans have instead of mythology. Being that they were all made up by the same rag-tag group of wolf fetishists and unwashed barbarians in the same network of caves and little huts, these stories are just well-suited to being thrust into the same place at the same time. (And people wonder why we smell like wet dog?) The one I'm reading now is called The Book of Lost Things by John Connolly, conveniently acquired for almost nothing as one of my trophies from the untimely death of Borders. I don't know what happens yet (beyond that it's a hero's journey), but it's such an amazing example of the genre that I just had to post about it before I was even done reading. Okay, so first off, I swear by all that has ever been holy that this book tells the backstory of Rolan from Valdemar. I think I might be the only person I know who is such a ponce as to read those books, but they are quite adorable* and if you ever knew who Rolan was you will shit yourself when he appears: companion, gay lover, brightware, and all. He even says something about how he doesn't know his way around this world because he has never traveled these roads before (as it is his first appearance in mythology aside from his own story). I had an orgasm of metafictional delight--a metaphorical one, don't be absurd. Now, Rolan (or Roland, for, like other companions in Valdemar canon, his name is mangled when he is reincarnated as a horse--oops, Valdemar spoiler.) is almost entirely irrelevant to the awesomeness of this book, so actually you can ignore my incoherent fangirling of him and focus on the rest: David is a 12-year-old boy living in London during the Blitz. The book opens with the death of his mother from a slow wasting sickness. This brings about changes in David's life: a new stepmother, eventually a new baby brother, a mysterious new home filled with strange books. The logical response is obviously to find a magical doorway into a strange land. This strange land is even stranger than most, though, all rife with sexual overtones and unusual ways of living. There is a silent king in a mysterious castle, who keeps the days in a grimoire, a Book of Lost Things; David's quest is to journey to this castle and ask the king to help him to return home. Along the way, David learns that things are rarely what they seem, that the stories he has been told and some of the things in which he believes are not-quite-right. The story manages to be self-referential in a way that is perfect; in the beginning, we are told that David once read the story of a knight on a quest to find a tower, but when the knight arrived, the tale ended and he never discovered what happened to the knight. Later, David goes along to the tower with that very knight, and the very same fate befalls the man. Something tells me the story, and many others David encountered in his books and then in his world, will be in the mysterious book at the end of the book. As I said, I haven't finished it, so I can't say precisely what might be happening yet, beyond of course, the obvious. Whatever it is, it is vital and disturbing. Edit: Having finally finished this, I have not very much more to say about it than that it was kind of the author to provide reprints of and notes on the origin of the fairy-tales he used. That was cool. Roland is actually from a poem by Robert Browning; the poem that David reads is that actual poem, and it is real. I stand by my assertion that Roland is Rolan from Valdemar anyhow. ... Other fab fairy-tale mashups to peruse: Red Riding Hood - I am anticipating getting around to watching this new film with baited breath for its treatment of big bad as a werewolf villager instead of as an allegorical forest entity. Also Gary Oldman, for whom I am a sucker. Fables by Bill Willingham & Mark Buckingham - a comic book series--the characters from our old stories must eke out a living in modern-day New York City. Into the Woods - Another one I've mentioned here before, this one is a stage musical that weaves together a great many of the old stories in a surprising way. Shrek, the whole 'verse, and Happily Never After and it's sequel which were the rip-off of Shrek but which I actually found to be rather entertaining and somewhat better-crafted in terms of the beloved old characters. You do have to listen to Andy Dick voice a purple cat, though. The Brothers Grimm - A film with Heath Ledger that I've raved about here before. It turns some things around; for instance, the woodsman is a woman and the big bad wolf is a woodsman. The Stinky Cheese Man And Other Fairly Stupid Tales - a book which is not for children, but appears to be. Please rec more in the comments, if you can think of any? *Finally, if you care who Rolan of Valdemar is, read Mercedes Lackey's Heralds series. I particularly recommend The Last Herald-Mage Trilogy, Magic's Promise, Magic's Pawn, and Magic's Price, which does not actually feature Rolan at all (he is dead at the time), but which makes for a great introduction and is in-text slashy and so is relevant to the subject of the journal. Rolan himself appears first in Arrows of the Queen.

I own some costumes, so that's quite a question.

I'm going to say it's a three-way toss-up between Morpheus' coat from The Sandman, Aphrodite-as-Stripper, and a Ren Faire gown. :/

...plus I have a tux with tails in my closet, which is pretty strange, considering.

So, apparently today is Women's Equality Day, of which I have never heard. I was planning to post this list today anyhow, but apparently it's a little topical. It will become obvious why. 5. Tiresias - We'll start with the original so you know what I'm on about. Tiresias, a blind prophet of Odyssean fame, once encountered two snakes copulating. He struck them with his staff and was transformed by the gods into a woman, apparently as punishment for bothering serpents. He lived as a woman for seven years, married and bore children, and then was transformed back. Later, he was able to settle a debate amongst the gods as to whether the male or the female receives more pleasure from sex. Tiresias' conclusion was that the female feels ten times the pleasure that the male does, so, arguably, the punishment for bothering the serpents may have actually been his transformation back after being given that knowledge. So, today's list is about men in fiction who are transformed into women and then back again. 4. Ranma Saotome, from Ranma 1/2 - Cheesy old anime being one of my many passions, I couldn't leave out Saotome. This is one of those long, sprawling epics, he has ongoing problems. It's fun. So, there's this cursed hotspring, teenage martial-arts enthusiast Ranma falls into it, then forever after cold water transforms him into a (redheaded?) girl, hot water transforms him back. Then he gets up to pretty much all the hijinks you would imagine a teenager with such a problem would get up to, plus it's in Japan where there are things like arranged marriage and public baths to worry about. 3. Hansel, from Hedwig and the Angry Inch - Hansel is an East-German teenager rescued by his lover, an American soldier, but the only way to rescue him is to legally marry him, and the only way to marry him is an assumed name and a brutal and botched surgery. The marriage doesn't work out, and Hedwig is abandoned in a strange land, strangely transformed. She does what any reasonable person would do in that situation and becomes a rock star. One could argue that Hansel is not transformed back from Hedwig -it would be impossible, technically speaking- though it seems to me he is, in the end, at least within his own mind. 2. James Kirk (whaaaat?), in the episode Turnabout Intruder - Our dear Captain, Starfleet's golden boy, was once brain-switched, if you will, into the body of a female archaeologist. She, in his body, tries to take over the Enterprise in some grandly symbolic bid to assuage her entirely Freudian-via-the-1960's penis-envy. It is interesting to note that, according to Dr. Janice Lester, women are still, in the year 2269, considered incapable of rising to many professions, including command of a starship. I have always suspected, though, that it is Dr. Janice Lester who couldn't have commanded, and that she refused to take responsibility for her own failure and instead blamed it on society hating her cunt. (Neither view is really provable from what I personally know of Trek. Women certainly command starships no more than 25 years later, for I recall a female captain in one of the films, 4 or 6 I think, to say nothing of Voyager 80 or so years later. But that's all era-relevant allegory, so whatever.) 1. Hunter Gathers, from The Venture Brothers - Hunter, who looks and sounds suspiciously like Johnny Depp as Hunter S. Thompson, is first introduced as the wiry little steak-eating spring-cosh-wielding mentor from Brock Sampson's Office of Secret Intelligence training days. "Are you ready for anything?" "Yes, sir!" "Are you still ready for anything?" He has always had a penchant for cross-dressing as a disguise while spying, and a primary lesson he teaches Brock is "no women, no children," meaning that as the good guys, the OSI must operate on the principles of chivalry; enemy women must be captured non-lethally and brought in for mundane justice. Years later, Brock discovers that Hunter has defected from the OSI and vanished, and he is instructed to track down and execute his old mentor for this betrayal. When he finds him, he discovers that Hunter has had a cutting edge sci-fi sex-change and Brock would be betraying Hunter's own teachings if he went through with his assignment to kill his old mentor. Startlingly, that's only the beginning of Hunter's story, and Hunter is only a bit player. (Remind me to just do a whole post one day on what marvelous fucking writers are Doc Hammer and Jackson Publick.)

Lying upon her breast, elbows forward and legs parted, her cheek resting in one hand, she was stabbing a pattern of tiny holes into a pillow of green linen, with a long golden pin. -- Aphrodite by Pierre Louÿs It was there when I woke up, I swear. The feeling. -- Gun, With Occasional Music by Jonathan Lethem Current theories on the Creation of the Universe state that, if it were created at all and didn't just start, as it were, unofficially, it came into being between ten and twenty billion years ago. -- Good Omens by Terry Pratchett and Neil Gaiman In the days when the spinning-wheels hummed busily in the farmhouses --and even great ladies, clothed in silk and thread-lace, had their toy spinning wheels of polished oak-- there might be seen in districts far away among the lanes, or deep in the bosom of the hills, certain pallid undersized men, who, by the side of the brawny country-folk looked like the remnants of a disinherited race. -- Silas Marner by George Elliot, who apparently shares my affinity for overlong sentences. ...and a great many more.

...to delightful effect. In all instances, these are the English titles and trailers for the English dubs, because that's how I roll. Also, some of these are loli girls and some are loli boys, because that's also how I roll. 5. Black Cat - An adorable and arguably brainwashed boy assassin, Train, meets a girl bounty-hunter, Saya, who changes his life forever. He changes her life far more drastically. 4. Black Butler - The titular character, Sebastian, is a butler with a Faustian backstory and the job of looking after a little boy who has sold his soul to the devil in exchange for revenge upon those who murdered his parents. Ciel is like an evil, eleven-year-old Batman who dresses really well. 3. Moon Phase - Kouhei, a young photographer looking for supernatural phenomena, finds a little vampire girl who attempts to make him her slave. It sort of works. Hazuki convinces Kouhei to take her home with him and protect her from her vampire family. 2. Gunslinger Girl - Set in Italy, this one tells the story of several little girls who would have died in terrible accidents --had the government not made cyborg assassins of them. 1. La Portrait de Petite Cossette - Eiri discovers a seemingly-magical goblet in which he sees visions of a beautiful young girl from the past. He becomes infatuated, and is horrified to discover that she was murdered, and even more horrified to discover exactly who murdered her.

This may look like a list with only three things on it, and it may seem logically as though it must have nine things on it, but it actually has thirteen! Anyhow: Three fantasy trilogies I loved in high school. Oh, and I just noticed they were all written by women, yay! These are for the most part geared towards young adults, and so each one is a quick and entertaining read. 3. The Harper Hall Trilogy - Dragonsong, Dragonsinger, and Dragondrums, by Anne McCaffrey. These books are a small side-adventure geared towards young adults in the infamous and enormous adult series, the Dragonriders of Pern. (HM: Nerilka's Story, a fourth book in the same series and vein, though not part of the Harper Hall Trilogy.) The first two volumes focus on Menolly, a young girl from some gross backwater hold who dreams of becoming a harper -even though girls can't be harpers. The third, Dragondrums, is about her young friend Piemur, a harper-in-training whose voice breaks unfortunately at puberty, leaving him to find a new path in life. 2. The Earthsea Trilogy - A Wizard of Earthsea, The Tombs of Atuan, and The Farthest Shore (HM: In my link-gathering for this I found out this is actually a trilogy of six: Tehanu, Tales from Earthsea, and The Other Wind, but it was a trilogy for a long time, to be fair.) by Ursula K. Le Guin. Ged is a young wizard with a few notable character flaws, and these get him into huge, life-altering, destiny-making trouble. Will he discover the name and the mastery of the darkness that follows him? 1. The Firebringer Trilogy - Birth of the Firebringer, Dark Moon, and The Son of Summer Stars by Meredith Ann Pierce. This story is about a herd of sentient warmongering unicorns and their quest to retake their homelands from hostile invaders. Jan, their war-prince, has many adventures, including fighting wyverns, discovering human civilization and horses, and finding dragons to impart wisdom upon him.

or, Wanderings with Werewolves. These are my fifteen favorite werewolves, and trailers, amazon links, etc. Such a fantastic archetype. Despite the title, the listers are not all male. Female werewolves are a bit hard to come by, but I feel I've represented them fairly. Before I get to the list, though, I'll wax analytical about the trope. Werewolves don't have anything bad in them that humans don't have, nor anything good. They are the polar opposite of those awful cold things that are so popular of late, vampires; werewolves symbolize life, wild and too-much. They can't eat enough to sate their hunger, they can't drink enough to slake their thirst, they can't fuck enough to satisfy their desire. They deserve some love in this literary horror-craze. In fact, they would probably more appreciate some lust. 15. Del Howison, if that is indeed your real name, author of When Werewolves Attack: A Field Guide to Dispatching Ravenous Flesh-Ripping Beasts - Despite Mr. Howison's unnecessarily long and censorious title and the apparent failure by both himself and his publisher to proofread, his guide is a delicious assembly of werewolf lore and history, well-researched and with bibliography(!) included. Makes a great jumping-off point for learning about historical werewolf trials, classical werewolf literature (and pop fiction), and so forth. Additionally, I suspect that had Mr. Howison edited his book a little more thoroughly, he might have realized that an alarming array of personal details and subtext hinting at the truth about his own condition was inadvertently allowed to remain in the final manuscript! 14. Wolf, from The 10th Kingdom - This is a 10 hour miniseries made by Hallmark, and it's a little meh, so I'll forgive you if you don't watch it, but Wolf is adorable so watch those scenes: lamb and warm milk in new york, bacon in the nine kingdoms, and the only vids I can find to demonstrate the adorable love plotline are fanmade music videos, so here is perhaps the silliest. The performance of this Balwdin-like fellow is the highlight of the entire 10 hours. (Try to ignore the horror that is a dog in the kitchen of a restaurant, that one is really a prince under a curse.) 13. Ginger from Ginger Snaps, Ginger Snaps 2: Unleashed, and honestly I like Ginger Snaps Back best, so check that out, too. 'If I wasn't here would you eat her?' Basically all you need to know about the first one is classic werewolf flick, but with hot sisters as wolf and wolf's human friend, plus a twist. The second one is all twist. The third one is in colonial America because it's a past life or something and it's just great. I particularly like that the saga uses as a plot device the transmission of lycanthropy by unprotected sex, which always seemed only logical to me. 12. The Surprise!Werewolf from Dog Soldiers - Spoiler alert: 'You may think all women are bitches, but I'm the real thing.' You'll want to watch this flick at least twice, because nothing is as it appears, not even with my giving you that massive spoiler I just gave. Plus the wolf effects are stellar and the soldiers are adorable. 11. The Woodsman, from The Brothers Grimm - This is a fun fairy tale mash-up flick by Terry Gilliam. The ironically-named old werewolf is a scary (and tragic!) villain all chock-full of daddy issues and manipulation. He boasts easily the coolest transformation sequence of any werewolf on the list. 10. Manuel Romasanta, from Romasanta: The Werewolf Hunt - Romasanta is the bad kind of werewolf. He kills little girls and makes a man gut and eat his still-living wife, and he manages to be a sympathetic and seductive character anyhow. (Or maybe I'm just messed-up. It is a distinct possibility.) This is made more horrifying by the film's assertion that it is based on a true story and is therefore about a serial killer instead of a literal werewolf. (A.K.A. Romasanta and Werewolf Hunter: Legend of Romasanta. Can be a pain to find.) 9. David, from An American Werewolf in London - David and his friend Jack, Americans on holiday, are attacked by a mysterious beast of the moors. Jack is killed, but David survives. Then there's jazz, sex, Tottenham Court, zombies, and other similar craziness. It's a comedy, really. A black one. Features perhaps the best use of the song Moondance in human history. 8. Henry, to avoid repetition, from The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde by Robert Louis Stevenson - Henry is the thinking man's werewolf. This is an example of the genre 'I thought I knew this because I saw a movie but whoa' so read it even though I know you already know the story. There will be a quiz. 7. Blue, from Wolf's Rain - This is one of those dark, symbolism-ridden anime series that only makes sense if you watch it seven times through, and I don't think I've seen it enough to quite understand it, but I still adore it. A group of wolves are seeking paradise on the recommendation of a prophecy. Blue is a female wolf who was raised by a human, and she must decide who and what she really is in the midst of the apocalypse. (She's the one with blue eyes and a collar.) 6. The Wolf, from Into the Woods - Fair warning, his costume = not safe for work in any way. He's the ultimate embodiment of Big Bad Wolf, right down to his leather tailcoat. Wait, what? Anyway, Into the Woods is a classic musical, and if you haven't seen it, you don't know from fairy tales, man. 5. Remus John Lupin, from Harry Potter - A professor, a father-figure, a resistance fighter, and a reluctant AIDS metaphor. His faults include bisexuality, exposition fever, and general failure to remember any of the practical concerns of being a werewolf. Ps. That trailer has almost nothing to do with him, actually, but you get the idea. 4. Bigby Wolf, from Fables by Bill Willingham (A serialized graphic novel, or, 'comic' as the kids call them.) - A hard-boiled detective, Bigby keeps everything in order these days, for the fairy-tale creatures have much bigger, badder problems than wolves. I particularly love the way Bigby is painted as the faithful and loving (if messy) alternative to Snow White's two-timing conman prince ex-husband -but, of course, Bibgy's just her dog. 3. Mowgli, from The Jungle Book by Rudyard Kipling - 'The Wolf that shall keep it may prosper, but the Wolf that shall break it must die.' Another example of I know you've seen the film but go read it anyhow. Mowgli is not the typical wolf -he is a man-cub raised by wolves. Like so many wolves on this list, Mowgli faces a choice between his animal side and his human side. The Jungle Books I and II also feature tons of other charming and mildly disturbing tales of colonial India. 2. Vivian Gandillon from Blood and Chocolate by Anette Curtis Clause - Also a film adaptation which could not have been more different to the book (did not even take place in the same country) but was totally sweet anyhow. Vivian falls in love with a meat-boy, and she has to decide between loving him and being with her family, being her true self. Stunning story, in both incarnations, but, uhm, don't just see the movie because they have different meanings and say different things, and if you're committing to this, you need to get both stories. It's a quick read, totally worth it. 1. Jacob Badass Motherfucker Marlowe, from The Last Werewolf by Glen Duncan - Jake is a feisty fucker who has nonetheless lost his will to live. 'I just don't want any more life.' This guy gets it, man. You'll be right there with Jake as he contemplates the death of his species and what to do next. Bonus: Werewolves.com, base camp for werewolf fiction, and The Werewolf Page - a little sampler of classic and modern short stories. .

A sampling of genres and studios, these are all silly good fun at first glance, but then, oh my... 5. Strike Witches - This WWII-era alternate universe seems to be just fanservice, and to be fair, there are a great many shots of tightly-wrapped poon, but it's a touching tale of scared young girls defending their homelands from a terrifying enemy because it is their duty to do so. 4. Chobits - Supercomputers shaped like cooperative hot girls? Sign me up! Oh but then it turns out to have tragic backstory and to be a gutting metaphor. 3. Magical Shopping Arcade Abenobashi - Arumi and Sashi, a little girl and boy from Osaka (which is apparently Houston, Texas), go on a magical fantasy journey because they don't want to grow up. 2. GTO: Great Teacher Onizuka - No magical girls, no giant robots, no aliens, as one of the promos says; just a story that you'll want to watch over and over. Onizuka Eikichi is a 22-year old teacher fresh out of school, and the former leader of a gang of yanki bikers. Is he in it for the high school girls, or is teaching his true and noble calling? 1. FLCL - 'What does Fooly Cooly mean, anyway?' If you have to ask, you'll find out when you're older.

NB: Aside from reviews and lists, this journal is friends-only, so if you've found your way here from some corner of the internet looking for the fics archive, comment here and I'll add you.

Nothing personal, just, ya know, spider bots give me shivers.

Well this is oddly topical, isn't it?

At least one will fall. Probably both will, and then they'll get so wrapped up in trying to fly casual that they never admit it, and then it feels shallow even though it's not.

And that's the best possible outcome.

. I tend to make up for how boring and sad my longfics are by posting dozens of short smut fics, and this is the index for them. Some are old and some are new, many are Remus/Sirius but some are not, and they are all smutty--rated NC-17. Full of cock. . Madhouse Lovenest: Madhouse Lovenest: Remus/Sirius. This is a series of loosely-connected Grimmauld Place-era smut. Sirius is in quite dire straits after his imprisonment and his other traumas, and Remus tries his best to help him, though he is beginning to lose control of himself to the wolf. Please see warnings on individual fics: this is rather grim and sometimes involves a sort of dominance play which might be unhealthy or which might look unhealthy, as well as actual violence, drinking, sexual encounters with ladies, and other things which you might not be here for. . Other: Twice: Remus/Sirius. Time Travel challenge: Remus is recognised by the cleverest boy in the world. NC-17. Priceless: Remus/Sirius. Sirius is a sex worker challenge: "I couldn't have afforded to decline such an arrangement." NC-17. The Spectre of Sirius: Remus/Sirius. Ghost challenge: "I'm not sure how I could have forgotten about the portrait." NC-17. Warning (Highlight):A portrait was painted of Sirius when he was in school, age unspecified. Remus gets off to it. Venom: Fenrir/Remus and Remus/Sirius, HBP-Era. Remus goes back to Fenrir. NC-17. Warning (Highlight):Present: Utter noncon I have no excuse. Past: It is implied (vaguely stated?) that Fenrir sexually abused Remus as a child. A Boy With A Dog's Soul: Remus/Sirius. Knotting challenge: Sirius convinces Remus to give in to wilder urges. (They're both in human form, it's a werewolf thing.) NC-17. Shower: Sirius entertains a crush on a fellow 7th-year Gryffindor quidditch player. Sirius/Anonymous!Bloke. NC-17. Little Red: In some vague future AU where nobody is dead and everybody is an adult, Ginny encounters the big bad wolf. Ginny/Remus, NC-17. Anarchy: Never mind the bollocks, here's the sex... Just two punks, having some fun. Remus/Sirius, NC-17. Wooden Dagger: What Professor Lupin And Mister Giles Got Up To In Romania: Once upon a time I wrote a plot arc of lulzy/porny Buffy/HP xover. Most of it vanished into the singularity that was the destruction or migration of , but I have found some of it and am reposting that as well. (I was awful at archiving.) NC-17. Fraternizing With: Remus, back at Hogwarts to teach, can't sleep. A fugitive pays him a visit, and the two find guilt-ridden release. Remus/Sirius. NC-17. .

Monaco, because there I could spend an unparalleled amount of someone else's money. Sure it's a principality, but close enough.

Here is a list of names from Arthurian legend. It's primary purpose is to help breeders of Opalescent dragons to choose an Arthurian name, if they should so desire. I can see how it might be useful for other things, too, though, so use it as you see fit. Or ignore it. From T.H. White's Once and Future King & The Book of Merlyn: WIP -I'm maybe a fifth of the way through the book. I mean, I've read it before, but my name-gathering is like a fifth of the way through. I will keep updating this post, when I'm again bored enough to go through a book and write down the names. This is, of course, not the original text of the Arthurian legend, so a great many of these names appear only in T.H. White's version of the tale, but that has been generally accepted as... at least as canonical as anything else. Because Camelot was never about real life, it was always about stories. Characters in approximate order of appearance: Sir Ector Sir Kay The Wart Merlyn / Merlin Sir Grummore (surname Grummurrsum) Galapis King Pellinore Sir Hob Sir Cully / Colonel Cully Old Jack / Black Peter / King of the Moat (same char) Sir Lancelot / Sir Launcelot du Lac Balan The Rabbi Jachanan Robin Wood (Yes, he's Robin Hood -see *) Morgan le Fay William Twyti Crumbocke of Forest Sauvage Lord Baden-Powel King Uther Pendragon Igraine of Cornwall *Robin Hood: -actually in White, Merlin and Wart encounter many characters from the Robin Hood story: John Naylor / Little John, Maid Marian, Friar Tuck, Scathelock / Scarlett. This is okay because Merlyn is a time-traveller, and/or Arthur is hallucinating.) Arthurian Names found Googling: These are more the historical / older-text versions of things from various sources around the web. There is overlap with celtic and really-old-christian mythology. Names are masc. unless noted otherwise. Gorlois, or The Duke of Cornwall, (Husband of Igraine) Amlawdd (Mother of Igraine) Vortigern (King before Uther, possibly a title rather than name) Morgana, Morgause, Orcades or Morchades, Anna, Mabuz, Mabon, (alternate names for Morgan le Fay, the half-sister of Arthur and mother of Mordred.) King Lot Luwddoc, alternately knwown as Gwyar, (A husband of Morgan le Fay) Accolon (A lover of Morgan le Fay) King Uriens (A husband of Morgan le Fay) Yvain or Ywain Ettarde Pelleas Sir Gaheris Sir Agravain Sir Gareth Sir Lamorak Sir Bors de Ganis Sir Geraint Sir Tristan or Tristram Sir Percivale Sir Bedivere Sir Robin the Brave (Okay, that one's from Monty Python) King Ban of Benwick (Lancelot's Father) Queen Elaine (Lancelot's Mother) Elaine of Astolat (Lancelot's mad wife, mother of Galahad) Gwagged Annwn (a celtic water spirit, Lady of the Lake probably was one) Vivien, Nineve, Nimue, Niniane (names for the Lady of the Lake) Iseult or Isolde (f) King Anguish of Ireland (Father of Isolde) Sir Bertilak, The Green Knight, and Sir Pertilope, The Green Knight (diff. guysapparently, despite similar names & same title?) Pelles, Parlam, Pellen, Bron, or Anfortas, names for The Fisher King Gwion Gwreang (f) Ceridwen, Keridwen, etc. (f) Guiomar (f) (A cousin of Guinevere) Gwenhwyfach (f) (A sister of Guinevere) From kingarthursknights.com: 'There is also an ancient Triad of the Island of Britain which records Arthur's "Three Chief Queens": Gwenhwyfar daughter of Cywryd, Gwenhwyfar daughter of Gwythyr ap Greidiol and Gwenhwyfar daughter of Ogrfan Gawr.' So there may have been as many as three Gueneveres and nobody realizes it. Other names for Guenevere's father: King Leodegrance, King Lleudd-Ogrfan of Cameliard, King Garlin of Galore. Place Names: Joyeux Garde (Lancelot's Castle) Camelot Avalon, The Fortunate Isle, or The Isle of Apples The Castle of the Forest Sauvage Castle Chariot (Morgan le Fay's castle) Gramarye, Logres, (old names for England) Tintagel Castle (Igraine's castle) St. Michael's Mount Caer Gal Castell y Cnwclas (Knucklas Castle) Other Cool Words: The Beast Glatisant Archimedes (an owl) Pax (latin for peace) Beast of the Foot Holy Grail Excalibur PS: EGGSPAM!

Apparently Twilight might actually be Mormon propaganda designed to teach young girls to be submissive to their controlling husbands. Tragically, it's just another messed-up fairy tale, right? The morality fables of society have been doing that to women since time immemorial. 'Don't go into the woods or the big bad wolf will get you!' (read: you might lose your virginity!) 'If people treat you badly, just do what you're told until your future husband comes to save you!' I hate to have to sound so, ya know, uppity. But come on. Men really opened the door on this crap themselves when they taught us to read. (But then, it was written by a woman -supposedly.) So, go forth and read these interesting reviews. Maybe even investigate the books themselves on the way...

A recent post on some community made me think about some of the responses I've had over the years to my piercings.  I have two rings in my lower lip, positioned just below my canine teeth. Me: Uh...  Thanks? 

-

-

Me: Thanks.

-

-

Me: (looking around to see if I have toilet paper stuck to my shoes or something) Huh?
Jerk: Those rings in your face!
Me: *shrug*  I like them.
Jerk:  Well, I'd never date a girl who did that to herself.
Me: Good, she wouldn't date you either.

-
Woman at Shop: You know you've got rings in your face?
Me: WHAT? Really?  Omfg.

I have discovered a movie which is gayer than the director's cut of Alexander. The History Boys. Ostensibly, the premise is that it's the final term at a classy grammar school and the unruly-but-witty oxbridge set is getting ready for their exams with the help of two masters; the old one is played by the guy who played Vernon Durseley, actually, though his performance is mind-blowingly above the bar set by playing 'mean uncle number one'. Despite the mind-boggling amount of gay, none of it was mentioned on the back cover, so I thought it was going to be like a British Dead Poets Society -and in truth it was, just gayer. The old master is a creepy lester (the transmission of knowledge itself is an erotic act, he says) who fondles everyone and is half in love with the blond boy, the blond boy is head over heels in love with the slutty brunette boy, but the brunette just wants to sleep with the shy virgin secretary and suck off the young master (it is not his gap year, but only barely -he is about five minutes older than us, says one of the boys), who is too preoccupied with hating the old master (and therefore himself because he is in the same position) to take him up on it even though it would have been quite sweet (the distinction is that the brunette, certainly almost seventeen, came to the young master as an equal and tried to seduce him, wrong as that may sound, rather than getting felt up against his will on the back of a motorbike). I won't spoil the ending, but they actually made me pity and then despite myself love the creepy old lester. It is based on a play, and at times it seems like you're watching a play, particularly the innovative (or hackneyed, depending upon how you look at it) finale. The moral might have been 'si tu comprendes, tu pardonnes' -if you can understand you can forgive. (forgive the bad french, it's been six years since I had a class and they only said it, they didn't spell it.) In conclusion; worth watching even if only for the gay, and a great story at that.

I saw a great movie last night.  Werewolf Hunter: The Legend of Romasanta.  (I thought it was going to be werewolf-hunter, but it was actually werewolf, hunter.)  Made in 2004 and starring Professor Lupin's heterosexual brother, Julian Sands, as either a werewolf or a serial killer.  You decide!  It's set in 1851 in Spain, and based on the tale of an actual serial killer whose defense plea was lycanthropy. It has some really nice performances from a bunch of people I never heard of, plus a really appalling werewolf transformation sequence.  Oh, wait, did I just give it away?  Well, it might be a visual representation of a symbolic transformation.  It was one of those films that's a little hard to follow, on purpose I think.  I love those.

http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0374180/

I saw Sofia Coppola's Marie Antoinette yesterday. Try as I might, the only meaning I could take away from it was that if you plan to make a biopic, you ought to choose someone worth biographing. I have never seen a stupider or more meaningless film. Kirsten Dunst did a great job as a vapid, clueless teenager who couldn't even figure out how to get pregnant; I totally believed that she knew nothing about anything -which must have been the point. The perhaps seventeen different awkward scenes where she tries to get Louis to respond to her (all filmed from the same angle on the same set) killed my own sex drive for the evening, and the endless montages of pretty fabrics and silly cakes looked like adverts. However, someone decided (apparently at the last minute) to try to make her a sympathetic figure; one quick scene towards the end indicates she is aware of the starving peasants, but rather than do anything about it, she tells her assistant to tell the jeweller to send her no more diamonds -as though this would have any effect but to starve the jeweller as well! Finally, in the last five minutes of the film, the peasants get restless. The opportunity to play with her dual images -the vapid child and the cruel empress that the peasants characterized her as- is totally wasted; we see a few seconds of her reading a tabloid to her ladies in waiting and giggling over it. Finally, revolution comes; we see the royal family cower for a bit, and then the credits roll. The WTFitude is incredible. The only think that I could think might be the point of the film is one quick shot. During one of the tedious 'lets have tailors come round and show us things to buy' scenes, Marie is trying on shoes. For not even two whole seconds, a pair of lace-up converse tennis shoes is visible in the background. Perhaps this is the directrix's way of saying that the modern world is in for the same fate as the rococo one? Learn from history or repeat it must be the moral of the story, but damn was that a bad movie. I want to wash my eyes out with cake. ETA a random question having nothing to do with Marie Antoinette: Do English people ever use the phrase 'I double-dog-dare you to' blahblahblah? Because it would be awfully appropriate for something I'm thinking about, wouldn't it?

Meme from . Look out for spoilers, some for things you've never heard of. Which five fictional deaths have affected you the most? 1. Chrysis from Aphrodite by Pierre Louys. This may have been the first thing I ever read where a tragic hero caused her own demise, and it got me hooked! 2. Spock from Star Trek. I had the advantage of being very young (14?) when I fist saw Wrath of Kahn, and it blew me away!! And I didn't know he was coming back! And then when my dad rented The Search for Spock, I was on the edge of my seat the whole time. 3. Sirius Black. Though Snape's death was more poignant and more meaningful, Sirius Black was the one the narrator adored, the one the narrator was affected by. Yearg. The senselessness of it... Well. You know what I mean. 4. Da Whole World, yo in The Last Battle by C. S. Lewis. That whole series is riddled with symbolism I still don't understand, but the death of an entire magical world because there is no one left who needs to believe in it is pretty, uh, deep... 5. Wolfwood from Trigun. Didn't see it coming at all, I literally shrieked! Due to the nature of the work, though, it was all in good fun, and I can't say it had any lasting effect on me.
